title: Introduction to Ignite Talks
segmentation: We organize this with participation from data kind, and my colleague Paul Bradley and I were the main organizers, and here we like to thank the.
Group of people mentioned here who really did a good job helping us put this together in terms of getting leads and vetting them.
So the conference is about data for social good.
We wanted to bring together a representative group of organizations that are living and breathing.
This mantra of doing data for social good.
We had a somewhat constraint on time, so we optimized for variety.
We have organized a group of 10 representatives of various nonprofits doing various different types of missions.
Some of the organizational leaders and some of the actual data scientists and analysts who are utilizing the data.
Our MC for the evening is going to be jakpor way.
Executive director and founder of Data kind.
Jake has a PhD from UCLA.
He was formally a head of data science at the New York Times for a few years where he ran a lot of RND there.
He quit the New York Times with within a Commission and he found the data kind an I'll let Jake introduce data kind more formally, but data kind is an organization that is attempting to.
It's a matchmaker.
It's attempting to bring.
Data analysis and data practices more accessible to nonprofit and socially minded missions.
In the spirit of making data more accessible to people, Jake is also the host of National Geographics hit TV show the numbers game.
I'll check it out if anything.
This is just meant to make Jake blush.
So without.
If they do, I'd like to introduce Jake to the stage and he is going to introduce the majority of the speakers.
Thank you guys everybody.
It is a pleasure to be joining you in the ballroom from Tron, really a huge honor and thank you Brian and Paul.
So much for having me here.
These are the Ignite talks for KDD which is are going to be all about saving the world, but we're going to keep it quick.

As Brian mentioned, you're going to hear a lot of talks from people who are actually living and breathing doing data science for good and Brian actually gave a pretty good intro, but I wanted to say a little bit about my background and starting data kind because it started from a frustration that I think many of us have felt.
I started this with my cofounders Craig Borowski, Andrew Conway when we realized.
You know, we data scientists, machine learning people statisticians.
Seems like we've almost got superpowers.
We can, you know?
Mind terabytes of genomic data to come up with cancer drugs or guide the Hubble Telescope or Mars Rover into the extreme depths of the galaxies.
And yet, in our day jobs, most of us are building stuff.
Like this?
Apps to help you park your car.
Find better deals.
As Dan said, when Netflix recommends the Real Housewives of New Jersey to us, we have only ourselves to blame.
And it does to me.
Quite often.
The even more than that, you know the question would be, what do we do with this and what's exciting is that every organization is becoming a data organization.

Every field is having its data moment thanks to the data exhaust from cell phone, satellite imagery, open data, everyone can now use data, or at least a lot more people than could be for even groups like this.
So the group called Kilimo Salama that gives insurance to subsistence farmers in Africa, and they do this by a cell phone program where you can do payments by cell by cell phone.
Which means that now you have transactions, you have digital data about who is requesting the most when they're defaulting on their loans, what the weather is like.
So now this little NGO who would have thought of as a tech company, certainly can use the same kind of recommendation algorithms cluster analysis that we all use every day and yet they have.
No one to help them do that.
They designed this, aren't cheap, wouldn't even really know necessarily how to start.
And that's why I drew an I found a data kind to serve as a convener, so I'm going to bring data scientists together with mission driven organizations.

Whether that's just for a weekend at a data dive to quickly collaborate on something or long-term project in our data core program for six to nine months working together, we make it easy for data scientist to volunteer with social organizations.
And over just a few years that we've been around, we've been excited to see everything from groups working in ad tech.

Working with the New York City Parks Department to build statistical models to help them with the tree pruning programs might recognize Brian there, guiding intrepid team through some causal modeling or seeing groups from IBM and Mozilla Foundation actually look at satellite image.
To target the poorest areas of Kenya and Uganda, identifying roof types and hopefully people in here saw cushion brians talk earlier today for best social good paper.
This was an awesome project and really good stuff.
And that was the stuff that really excited us about this work and was what made us so excited that KDD's theme this year was around data science for social good.
And I was honored that Brian and Paul invited us to be apart of this because we said, you know, we always talk about how data scientists can go out and work with nonprofits and volunteer together.
But there are so many groups out there that are already doing this, and so tonight we want you guys to hear from people who are out there practicing data science at mission driven organizations.
I'm honored to say that we know many of these people.

Either personally or from working together and they are all fantastic and I'm incredibly excited to get to share with you the work that they have been doing, so I will get out of the way and let them come up.
But just so you guys know this is not a formal ignite, talking that the slides are not going to advance every 15 seconds.
If you've seen that kind of talk but they are going to be 5 minute talks so they can quickly come up and inspire you guys with the work that they're doing.
Now, exactly, if someone's already inspired.

Now we are going to have to leave here at exactly 7, so we're going to ask the people hold questions until the end, but all the speakers will be around in the reception, so you can please keep those ideas, talk to them and more importantly than that, if they have job openings.
If you want to work with them, this is an opportunity to start making those connections, so please please do reach out.
That is a lot of why we wanted to do this.
